bibl.title: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, April 27, 1924

div1.p: [Carter] thanks Fricks for a reference. [Carter] explains his health and discusses how important it is that he completes his work on Section III of the History of Yellow Fever so that other scientists can work forward from his conclusions.

div1.head: Letter fragment from [Henry Rose Carter] to Lunsford D. Fricks, April 27, 1924

opener.dateline:
2121. California St. N. W.
Washington DC
April 27/24

div1.p:
Thanks for you reference for the
Russian malaria. I did not receive
the original letter, 9,000,000 cases is the
estimate as I recall- I read it a few days ago.
I do not however see the details of which
you spoke. (1) Of it being a Winter epi-
demic & (2) House breeding of Anopheles.
theWhere did you a can I find that
data.

I am feeling exceptionally well, except for
the pain in my back & leg & that is no wise unbearable & have been
I think getting better since the middle of
March, I, or rather Laura, have, (a has) secu-
red quaters, for us across the street. where I
can go up stair's in an elevator & so
after June 1stI will be able to get
out of door's, which I have greatly missed
& which I think will be both pleasant &
good for me, since my arrival here Nov 15. I
have been on this floor & for 6 weeks previously
in one room & a porch- at Hopkins.

Still there is a good deal in life for me. David
to the contrary-the last 2½ year's have not
been “labor and sorrow”, I have done
2
some, not a great deal naturally, of use
fu work some of which was useful & (except when in pain) not
had a bad, (& never an uninteresting)
time.

I hope to finish in MayJune or maybe in
July the 3d section of my “His'y of Yel-
low Fever.” I am working on it regularly
everyday now, as long as my physician will
let me be up- about 3 hours (& 4 days a
week when I don't have to take massage
an hour. I rise extra which I usually
make 1½ hours).

I think that will be as far as I can go, as I
will need more data & would have to go
to the Congressional Library for it. I can
get books from the S.G. (Army) Li-
brary but there are many I want
which they have not & only occasion-
ally through Cumming or McCoy (who has
been extremely nice to me) can I get one from
the Congressional. Well I can't do
Well I could not have done much
more work any how. I will be 72 - on Aug
25th). 9 192, 2-10

The Congressional Library has been ex-
3
tremely nice to me. They had an manuscript M.SS.
at the Vatican photostated for me!
Said they “had been intending to ask
this for some year's & this was as good
a time as any”, I have too a copy (photo-
stat) also of Joaão Ferreyra da Rosa's
account of “The Fever of Olinda”. Tra
“Trattado Unico da Constiticiõ Pestilen-
çial à Pernambuco”. It is not a very
old book but rare. This was taken for me
at the British museum (I found afterwards
that I did not need it) but is rare. No copy
printed (& I suspect none other photostated)
in the U.S. that the Librarian could hear of.
Theere are 2 in the Escurial & I have no doubt
others in Lisbon. It is the first considered
“the first account of what may have been
Y.F. by a physician”. Says Béranger-Feráud
It certainly was Y.F. as certainly as that we
had in Peru.

I have had, I suspect, better facilities
for this work than any other man has ever-
had: I mean who has attempted it, & I would
have liked well to have finished it
still if I can finish section III. “The
Place
4
Place of Origin of Yellow Fever”. I
am content, To advance knowledge
by one complete step, so completely & certainly-
that the next man may begin a step
higher than the last man, is worth
while, well worth while. I did that in the
Epidemiology of Y. F. & this, plus
Ross' malaria work, directly - almost
inevitably I think - led to Reed's Que
mados experiments. T

That was a big thing in - what it led another
man to do: in the foundation it gave him.
This - the Sect III - is comparatively trivial, but
if I can settle the question, so that no
one else will feel the need of further exam-
ination, it will be a step added to our
knowledge. Also, it may have a bearing
on the sanitary work against Y.F. Where
it evolved, is where, if anywhere, we w'd
expect to find other vectors besides aegypti
& even possibly animal resevoir hosts!
There are neither in the Americas (asso-
ciated with men in the topics)- but Africa
has never been tested for them either
experimentally or epidemiologically.
